Variables
SharpNeat.​Experiments
namespace SharpNeat.Experiments
INeatExperiment
public interface
INeatExperiment​<T>
where T : struct
NeatExperiment

An interface that brings together a number of settings objects that make up a given experiment.

Type Parameter
T

Black box numeric data type.

Properties
FactoryId
string FactoryId { get }

Matches INeatExperimentFactory.Id from the experiment factory that created the current experiment instance.

It is possible to create INeatExperiment{T} without using an INeatExperimentFactory, in those cases this property can be set to null.

Id
string Id { get; set }

A unique human-readable ID associated with the experiment.

This will often match FactoryId, but there could be two or more experiments that are created from the same INeatExperimentFactory , and differ only by their configuration settings.

Name
string Name { get; set }

Experiment name.

Description
string Description { get; set }

Experiment description.

EvaluationScheme
IBlackBoxEvaluationScheme<T> EvaluationScheme { get }

Experiment evaluation scheme object.

IsAcyclic
bool IsAcyclic { get; set }

A boolean flag that indicates if the genomes that are evolved are acyclic, i.e. they should have no recurrent/cyclic connection paths.

CyclesPerActivation
int CyclesPerActivation { get; set }

For cyclic neural networks (i.e. if IsAcyclic is false) this defines how many timesteps to run the neural net per call to Activate().

ActivationFnName
string ActivationFnName { get; set }

Name of the neuron activation function to use in evolved networks.

EvolutionAlgorithmSettings
NeatEvolutionAlgorithmSettings EvolutionAlgorithmSettings { get }

The EvolutionAlgorithmSettings to be used for the experiment.

ReproductionAsexualSettings
NeatReproductionAsexualSettings ReproductionAsexualSettings { get }

The asexual reproduction settings to use for the experiment.

ReproductionSexualSettings
NeatReproductionSexualSettings ReproductionSexualSettings { get }

The sexual reproduction settings to use for the experiment.

PopulationSize
int PopulationSize { get; set }

The population size to use for the experiment.

InitialInterconnectionsProportion
double InitialInterconnectionsProportion { get; set }

The initial interconnections proportion. This is the proportion of possible direct connections from the input nodes to the output nodes that are to be created in each initial genome. The connections to create are selected at random (using a select-without-replacement method).

ConnectionWeightScale
double ConnectionWeightScale { get; set }

The maximum connection weight scale/magnitude.  E.g. a value of 5 defines a weight range of -5 to 5.  The weight range is strictly enforced, e.g. when creating new connections and mutating existing ones.

ComplexityRegulationStrategy
IComplexityRegulationStrategy ComplexityRegulationStrategy { get; set }

The complexity regulation strategy to use for the experiment.

DegreeOfParallelism
int DegreeOfParallelism { get; set }

The number of CPU threads to distribute work to.  Set to -1 to use a thread count that matches the number of logical CPU cores.

EnableHardwareAcceleratedNeuralNets
bool EnableHardwareAcceleratedNeuralNets { get; set }

Enable use of hardware accelerated neural network implementations, i.e. alternate implementations that use CPU SIMD/vector instructions.

The vectorized code is provided by alternative classes, and these classes tend to be more complex than their 'baseline' non-vectorized equivalents. Therefore when debugging a problem it is often useful to disable use of all vectorized code so as to rule out that code as the source of a problem/bug.  Furthermore, enabling hardware acceleration has been observed to often result in slower execution speed, probably because NEAT deals with non-homogeneous, irregular neural network structures that are generally not conducive to the application of vectorized code.

EnableHardwareAcceleratedActivationFunctions
bool EnableHardwareAcceleratedActivationFunctions { get; set }

Enable use of hardware accelerated neural network activation functions, i.e. alternate implementations that use CPU SIMD/vector instructions.

The vectorized code is provided by alternative classes, and these classes tend to be more complex than their 'baseline' non-vectorized equivalents. Therefore when debugging a problem it is often useful to disable use of all vectorized code so as to rule out that code as the source of a problem/bug.  Furthermore, enabling hardware acceleration has been observed to often result in slower execution speed, probably because NEAT deals with non-homogeneous, irregular neural network structures that are generally not conducive to the application of vectorized code.
